sentence.text: Rhabdomyolysis secondary to a drug interaction between simvastatin and clarithromycin.
OBJECTIVE: To report a case of rhabdomyolysis resulting from concomitant use of clarithromycin and simvastatin.
About three weeks prior to admission, the patient was started on clarithromycin for sinusitis.
The patient had been receiving simvastatin for approximately six months.
He was treated aggressively with intravenous hydration, sodium bicarbonate, and hemodialysis.
DISCUSSION: Clarithromycin is a potent inhibitor of CYP3A4, the major enzyme responsible for simvastatin metabolism.
The concomitant administration of macrolide antibiotics and other hydroxymethylglutaryl coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) reductase inhibitors have resulted in previous reports of rhabdomyolysis.

Other factors may increase the risk of this drug interaction, including the administration of other medications that are associated with myopathy, underlying renal insufficiency, and administration of high doses of HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors.
